citeinfo.origin: WCMC by the Land Information Centre (LIC) of the Ministry
citeinfo.title: Forest Cover, Maya Forest, Belize (Northeast), 1995

citeinfo.origin: University of Florida; Wildlife Conservation Society; Caribbean Conservation Corporation
citeinfo.title: Digital Geographic Database, Maya Forest Region

pubinfo.publish: The Paseo Pantera Consortium, University of Florida, USAID

descript.abstract: This is a digital database of the Maya Forest Region of Mexico, Guatemala, and Belize. Coverages presented here are ArcView Shape files. The projection is UTM Zone 16, using the NAD 1927 datum and the Clarke 1866 spheriod. This is a polygon coverage of forest cover types for the ares of Belize within the study area.
descript.purpose: To preserve biological diversity in Central America by improving stewardship of the region's protected areas and by expanding them to include unprotected wildlands and by restoring degraded areas that link the fragmented wildlands and isthmus. The data was gathered in a larger context to demonstrate the relationship of the Region and adjacent regions, to facilitate the identification of potential biological connections between the protected areas of the Maya Forest and those in adjacent regions, and to focus on ecological boundaries (not political boundaries).
descript.supplinf: The following description was provided by the WCMC: Forest cover data for Belize was made available to WCMC bythe Land Information Centre (LIC) of the Ministry of Natural Resources, Belmopan. David Gray of LIC, kindly provided a digital dataset of forest at a scale of 1:500,000, harmonized into simplified broad forest categories. The distribution of each forest type in the LIC dataset was derived from land system maps of the Land Resource Assessments compiled by Bruse King et al.. (1986, 1989 and 1992). of the Natural Resources Institute (NRI),UK. It must be noted, however, that because the forest cover has been estimated from the NRI Land Systems survey (i.e. the extent of each firest type was estimated by extracting land known to be under cultivation form 1985 -1989), this map should be seen as a first approximation at measuring the forest resources of Belize.Mangrove cover for the outlying cays has been added from a supplementry file provided by the Land Information Center,and is based on Zisman, S. (1992) Mangroves in belize: their characteristics, use and conservation, an unpublished report for the Forest Planning and Management Project. the NRI land system units, mapped to show agricultural potential of Belize, were assigned to the following forest classification: broadleaf cover (>75% tree canopy cover); open broadleaf cover (25%-75%); mixed broadleaf and pine (>75%); pine woodland (>75%), mangrove (>5%) and non-forest cover (<5%). Canopy cover was determined by interpreting a sample of 1:40,000 scale aerial photographs, however determination was indicative only. It is important to note that the broadleaf category is very generalized. This class is a mixture of a wide range of forest types ranging from low scrubby woodlands to tall species-rich forests The match between land systems units and forest types varied, with good correlations for pine forest, marsh/swamp forest and non-forest. However, because the broadleaf classification is so general, the only way the extent of this class could be derived was by subtracting the area of all the other classes from the total area of Belize. This inevitably will have introduced inaccuracies. The following forest classes have been amalgamated into the broad forest types. Lowland rain forest - Broadleaf forest and Open broadleaf forest; pine forest - Pine woodland, Pine woodland savanna and Mixed broadleaf/pine forest; inland swamp forest - Marsh/swamp; mangrove - Mangrove; and non-forest - Pine tree savanna and Non-forest

Carr, Principal Investigator, Department of Landscape Architecture, 431 ARCH, University of Florida, Gainesville, FL 32611, USA.

stdorder.nondig: Version 1 of the Digital Geographic Database for the Maya Forest Region of Mexico, Guatemala and Belize, of which you are in receipt, has been provided by the Department of Lancscape Architecture and the Geoplan Center, Department of Urban and Regional Planning at the University of Florida, Gainsville, Florida, USA for use in non-commercial scientific research and conservation planning. The project was sponsered by the Paseo Pantera Consortium formed by the Meso-American Program of the Wildlife Conservation Society and the Caribbean Conservation Corporation, Gainesville, Florida, USA. The project was funded by the U. S. Agency for International Development, Mission to Guatemala - Central American Programs (USAID/G-CAP). The researcher agrees to the following for use of Version 1 of Digital Geographic Database for the Maya Forest region of Mexico, Guatemala and Belize: 1) The data will not be sold 2) The primary and secondary sources of the data (Universty of Florida, Paseo Pantera Consortium and USAID/GCAP and other entities lised in the Version 1 Documentation) will be acknowledged in any derived data product, reports or publications. The data will not be dsitributed to third parties. who wish to obtain the digital data must complete their own request for data and agreement forms.
